text: , also known as Katsuo-dera,Murry, John et al. (1907). A handbook for travellers in Japan including the whole empire from Saghalien to Formosa, p. 367. is a Japanese Buddhist temple in Minō, which is in the mountains of northern Osaka Prefecture.Röpke, Ian Martin. (1999). Historical Dictionary of Osaka and Kyoto, p. 64. Katsuō-ji is one in a grouping of Buddhist temples which are pilgrimage sites in the Kansai region. ==History== The temple site was first named Miroku-ji in 765.Gautam, Neeraj. (2009). Buddha his life and teaching, p. 170. The name "Katsuō-ji" was given by the Emperor Seiwa. In 1184, the temple was destroyed by fire, but it was re-built. ==Daruma== Daruma dolls are often returned to the temple and left somewhere on the grounds. ==References== ==Other websites== *Katsuō-ji website Category:Buddhist temples in Japan Category:760s establishments in Japan Category:8th-century buildings and structures Category:Osaka Prefecture
title: Katsuō-ji
